channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Greetings from Guatemala, where one person's trash becomes another's colorful art
item.description: Far-Flung Postcards is a weekly series in which NPR's international team shares moments from their lives and work around the world.
item.content:encoded: Far-Flung Postcards is a weekly series in which NPR's international team shares moments from their lives and work around the world.
item.dc:creator: Greg Dixon

item.title: Government shutdown odds increase. And, Trump shifts stance on Russia-Ukraine war
item.description: President Trump canceled a meeting Democrats, increasing the odds of a potential government shutdown. And, the president suggests that Ukraine could win back all the territory it lost to Russia.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump canceled a meeting Democrats, increasing the odds of a potential government shutdown. And, the president suggests that Ukraine could win back all the territory it lost to Russia.

(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: New York City may move its mayoral elections to even years. It'd be part of a trend
item.description: This fall, New York City voters will weigh in on a proposal that could move future city elections to even-numbered years. It's part of a growing trend to consolidate election dates.
item.content:encoded:
This fall, New York City voters will weigh in on a proposal that could move future city elections to even-numbered years. It's part of a growing trend to consolidate election dates.

(Image credit: Spencer Platt)
item.dc:creator: Ashley Lopez

item.title: Love pumpkin spice lattes? Learn some of its spicy history
item.description: For NPR's Word of the Week: Things are getting spicy. We explain how a word referring to cinnamon and pepper turned less literal by the 19th century.
item.content:encoded:
For NPR's Word of the Week: Things are getting spicy. We explain how a word referring to cinnamon and pepper turned less literal by the 19th century.

(Image credit: Rizwan Tabassum/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Diaz

item.title: NPR's middle school champion: A moving podcast about Japanese incarceration
item.description: For the first time, NPR's Student Podcast Challenge has a returning champion: a California fifth grader who explored a dark chapter in U.S. history during World War II.
item.content:encoded:
For the first time, NPR's Student Podcast Challenge has a returning champion: a California fifth grader who explored a dark chapter in U.S. history during World War II.

(Image credit: Talia Herman)
item.dc:creator: Janet W. Lee

item.title: Typhoon Ragasa batters Hong Kong and southern China
item.description: Typhoon Ragasa whipped waves taller than lampposts onto Hong Kong promenades and turned seas rough on the southern Chinese coast after leaving deadly destruction in Taiwan and the Philippines.
item.content:encoded:
Typhoon Ragasa whipped waves taller than lampposts onto Hong Kong promenades and turned seas rough on the southern Chinese coast after leaving deadly destruction in Taiwan and the Philippines.

(Image credit: Chan Long Hei)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: 'We have to speak out,' Jimmy Kimmel says in his late-night return
item.description: The comedian was suspended for nearly a week by ABC's parent company, Disney, before returning to airwaves on Tuesday night.
item.content:encoded:
The comedian was suspended for nearly a week by ABC's parent company, Disney, before returning to airwaves on Tuesday night.

(Image credit: Randy Holmes)
item.dc:creator: Clare Lombardo

item.title: Camp Mystic plans to reopen in Texas next summer, a year after floods killed 27
item.description: Camp Mystic plans to reopen next summer near the site where 27 girls and counselors died in a July flood.
item.content:encoded:
Camp Mystic plans to reopen next summer near the site where 27 girls and counselors died in a July flood.

(Image credit: Eli Hartman)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Want a seat at this synagogue for the High Holidays? You have to register to vote first
item.description: A Brooklyn synagogue has taken an unusual step by requiring congregants to show proof of voter registration in order to secure seats for High Holidays. Their biggest concern? The city's mayoral seat.
item.content:encoded:
A Brooklyn synagogue has taken an unusual step by requiring congregants to show proof of voter registration in order to secure seats for High Holidays. Their biggest concern? The city's mayoral seat.

(Image credit: Bebeto Matthews)
item.dc:creator: Sarah Ventre

item.title: Trump, in major shift, suggests Ukraine can win back territory long held by Russia
item.description: Last month, President Trump said Ukraine needed to be open to giving up some of its territory in peace talks with Russia. But those talks haven't happened. Now, he says Ukraine could win it all back.
item.content:encoded:
Last month, President Trump said Ukraine needed to be open to giving up some of its territory in peace talks with Russia. But those talks haven't happened. Now, he says Ukraine could win it all back.

(Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)
